access_lists.title: IP Extended Access-Lists (legacy model)
access_lists.description:
AVD currently supports 2 different data models for extended ACLs:

- The legacy `access_lists` data model, for compatibility with existing deployments
- The improved `ip_access_lists` data model, for access to more EOS features

Both data models can coexists without conflicts, as different keys are used: `access_lists` vs `ip_access_lists`.
Access list names must be unique.

The legacy data model supports simplified ACL definition with `sequence` to `action` mapping:

action.description:
Action as string
Example: "deny ip any any"
action.title: Action

aliases.description:
Multi-line string with one or more alias commands.

Example:

```yaml
aliases: |
  alias wr copy running-config startup-config
  alias siib show ip interface brief
```
aliases.title: Aliases

login.description: Multiline string ending with EOF on the last line
login.title: Login

motd.description: Multiline string ending with EOF on the last line
motd.title: Motd

vlan.description: VLAN value(s) or range(s) of VLAN values
vlan.title: VLAN

cos.description: CoS value(s) or range(s) of CoS values
cos.title: COS

community_lists.title: Community Lists (legacy model)
community_lists.description:
AVD supports 2 different data models for community lists:

- The legacy `community_lists` data model that can be used for compatibility with the existing deployments.
- The improved `ip_community_lists` data model.

Both data models can coexist without conflicts, as different keys are used: `community_lists` vs `ip_community_lists`.
Community list names must be unique.

The legacy data model supports simplified community list definition that only allows a single action to be defined as string:

custom_templates.title: Extensibility with Custom Templates
custom_templates.description:
- Custom templates can be added below the playbook directory.
- If a location above the directory is desired, a symbolic link can be used.
- Example under the `playbooks` directory create symbolic link with the following command:

  ```bash
  ln -s ../../shared_repo/custom_avd_templates/ ./custom_avd_templates
  ```

- The output will be rendered at the end of the configuration.
- The order of custom templates in the list can be important if they overlap.
- It is recommenended to use a `!` delimiter at the top of each custom template.

Add `custom_templates` to group/host variables:

items.description: Template relative path below playbook directory

cvx.description: CVX server features are not supported on physical switches. See `management_cvx` for client configurations.
cvx.title: CVX

daemon_terminattr.description:
You can either provide a list of IPs/FQDNs to target on-premise Cloudvision cluster or use DNS name for your Cloudvision as a Service instance.
Streaming to multiple clusters both on-prem and cloud service is supported.
> Note For TerminAttr version recommendation and EOS compatibility matrix, please refer to the latest TerminAttr Release Notes
  which always contain the latest recommended versions and minimum required versions per EOS release.

cvaddrs.description:
Streaming address(es) for CloudVision single cluster
- TCP 9910 is used for CV on-prem
- TCP 443 is used for CV as a Service
cvaddrs.title: Cvaddrs

cvaddrs.description:
Streaming address(es) for CloudVision cluster
- TCP 9910 is used for CV on-prem
- TCP 443 is used for CV as a Service
cvaddrs.title: Cvaddrs

cvauth.description: Authentication scheme used to connect to CloudVision
cvauth.title: Cvauth

cvobscurekeyfile.description: Encrypt the private key used for authentication to CloudVision
cvobscurekeyfile.title: Cvobscurekeyfile

cvproxy.description:
Proxy server through which CloudVision is reachable. Useful when the CloudVision server is hosted in the cloud.
The expected form is http://[user:password@]ip:port, e.g.: 'http://arista:arista@10.83.12.78:3128'. Available as of TerminAttr v1.13.0
cvproxy.title: Cvproxy

cvsourceip.description: Set source IP address in case of in-band managament
cvsourceip.title: Cvsourceip

cvvrf.description: The VRF to use to connect to CloudVision
cvvrf.title: Cvvrf

cvauth.description: Authentication scheme used to connect to CloudVision
cvauth.title: Cvauth

cvobscurekeyfile.description: Encrypt the private key used for authentication to CloudVision
cvobscurekeyfile.title: Cvobscurekeyfile

cvproxy.description:
Proxy server through which CloudVision is reachable. Useful when the CloudVision server is hosted in the cloud.
The expected form is http://[user:password@]ip:port, e.g.: 'http://arista:arista@10.83.12.78:3128'. Available as of TerminAttr v1.13.0
cvproxy.title: Cvproxy

cvsourceip.description: Set source IP address in case of in-band managament
cvsourceip.title: Cvsourceip

cvvrf.description: The VRF to use to connect to CloudVision
cvvrf.title: Cvvrf

cvgnmi.description: Stream states from EOS GNMI servers (Openconfig) to CloudVision. Available as of TerminAttr v1.13.1
cvgnmi.title: Cvgnmi

disable_aaa.description:
Disable AAA authorization and accounting.
When setting this flag, all commands pushed from CloudVision are applied directly to the CLI without authorization
disable_aaa.title: Disable AAA

grpcaddr.description:
Set the gRPC server address, the default is 127.0.0.1:6042
e.g. "MGMT/0.0.0.0:6042"
grpcaddr.title: Grpcaddr

ingestexclude.description:
Exclude paths from Sysdb on the ingest side.
e.g. "/Sysdb/cell/1/agent,/Sysdb/cell/2/agent"
ingestexclude.title: Ingestexclude

smashexcludes.description:
Exclude paths from the shared memory table.
e.g. "ale,flexCounter,hardware,kni,pulse,strata"
smashexcludes.title: Smashexcludes

taillogs.description:
Enable log file collection; /var/log/messages is streamed by default if no path is set.
e.g. "/var/log/messages"
taillogs.title: Taillogs

ecodhcpaddr.description: ECO DHCP Collector address or ECO DHCP Fingerprint listening address in standalone mode (default "127.0.0.1:67")
ecodhcpaddr.title: Ecodhcpaddr

ipfix.description:
Enable IPFIX provider (TerminAttr default is true).
This flag is enabled by default and does not have to be added to the daemon configuration.
ipfix.title: Ipfix

ipfixaddr.description: ECO IPFIX Collector address to listen on to receive IPFIX packets (TerminAttr default "127.0.0.1:4739").
ipfixaddr.title: Ipfixaddr

sflow.description: Enable sFlow provider (TerminAttr default is true).
sflow.title: Sflow

sflowaddr.description: ECO sFlow Collector address to listen on to receive sFlow packets (TerminAttr default "127.0.0.1:6343").
sflowaddr.title: Sflowaddr

cvconfig.description: Subscribe to dynamic device configuration from CloudVision (TerminAttr default is false).
cvconfig.title: Cvconfig

cvcompression.description:
The default compression scheme when streaming to CloudVision is gzip since TerminAttr 1.6.1 and CVP 2019.1.0.
There is no need to change the compression scheme.
cvcompression.title: Cvcompression

generate_default_config.description:
The `generate_default_config` knob allows to omit default EOS configuration.
This can be useful when leveraging `eos_cli_config_gen` to generate configlets with CloudVision.

The following commands will be omitted when `generate_default_config` is set to `false`:

- RANCID Content Type
- Hostname
- Default configuration for `aaa`
- Default configuration for `enable password`
- Transceiver qsfp default mode
- End of configuration delimiter
generate_default_config.title: Generate Default Config

items.description:
EOS CLI interface command
Example: "switchport mode access"

ip_access_lists.title: IP Extended Access-Lists (improved model)
ip_access_lists.description:
AVD currently supports 2 different data models for extended ACLs:

- The legacy `access_lists` data model, for compatibility with existing deployments
- The improved `ip_access_lists` data model, for access to more EOS features

Both data models can coexists without conflicts, as different keys are used: `access_lists` vs `ip_access_lists`.
Access list names must be unique.

The improved data model has a more sophisticated design documented below:

remark.description:
Comment up to 100 characters.
If remark is defined, other keys in acl entry will be ignored.
remark.title: Remark

action.description:
ACL action.
Required for standard entry.
action.title: Action

protocol.description:
ip, tcp, udp, icmp or other protocol name or number.
Required for standard entry.
protocol.title: Protocol

source.description:
any, A.B.C.D/E or A.B.C.D.
A.B.C.D without a mask means host.
Required for standard entry.
source.title: Source

items.description: TCP/UDP source port name or number.

destination.description:
any, A.B.C.D/E or A.B.C.D.
A.B.C.D without a mask means host.
Required for standard entry.
destination.title: Destination

items.description: TCP/UDP destination port name or number.

icmp_type.description: Message type name/number for ICMP packets.
icmp_type.title: ICMP Type

tracked.description: Match packets in existing ICMP/UDP/TCP connections.
tracked.title: Tracked

ip_access_lists_max_entries.description:
The `ip_access_lists` data model allows to limit the number of ACL entries that AVD is allowed to generate by defining `ip_access_lists_max_entries`.
Only normal entries under `ip_access_lists` will be counted, remarks will be ignored.
If the number is above the limit, the playbook will fail. This provides a simplified control over hardware utilization.
The numbers must be based on the hardware tests and AVD does not provide any guidance. Note that other EOS features may use the same hardware resources and affect the supported scale.
ip_access_lists_max_entries.title: IP Access Lists Max Entries

ip_community_lists.title: IP Community Lists
ip_community_lists.description:
AVD supports 2 different data models for community lists:

- The legacy `community_lists` data model that can be used for compatibility with the existing deployments.
- The improved `ip_community_lists` data model.

Both data models can coexist without conflicts, as different keys are used: `community_lists` vs `ip_community_lists`.
Community list names must be unique.

The improved data model has a better design documented below:

communities and regexp MUST not be configured together in the same entry
possible community strings are (case insensitive):
 - GSHUT
 - internet
 - local-as
 - no-advertise
 - no-export
 - <1-4294967040>
 - aa:nn

communities.description: If defined, a standard community-list will be configured
communities.title: Communities

regexp.description:
Regular Expression
If defined, a regex community-list will be configured
regexp.title: RegExp

proxy.description: Global proxy settings should be enabled before enabling per-vlan
proxy.title: Proxy

action.description:
Action as string
Example: "deny ipv6 any any"
action.title: Action

profile.description: Pre-defined profile 'internet' or user-defined profile name
profile.title: Profile

action.description:
Action as string
Example: "deny ipv6 any any"
action.title: Action

lacp.description: Set Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) parameters.

default.description: Enable LACPDU rate limiting by default on all ports.
default.title: Default

lacp.title: LACP

disabled.description:
If true, the user will be removed and all other settings are ignored.
Useful for removing the default "admin" user.
disabled.title: Disabled

privilege.description: Initial privilege level with local EXEC authorization.
privilege.title: Privilege

role.description: EOS RBAC Role to be assigned to the user such as "network-admin" or "network-operator"
role.title: Role

sha512_password.description:
SHA512 Hash of Password
Must be the hash of the password. By default EOS salts the password with the username, so the simplest is to generate the hash on an EOS device using the same username.
sha512_password.title: SHA512 Password

no_password.description: If set a password will not be configured for this user. "sha512_password" MUST not be defined for this user.
no_password.title: No Password

sequence_numbers.description: Add sequence numbers to log messages
sequence_numbers.title: Sequence Numbers

eos_cli.description: EOS CLI rendered directly on the loopback interface in the final EOS configuration
eos_cli.title: EOS CLI

notification_timestamp.description:
Per the GNMI specification, the default timestamp field of a notification message is set to be
the time at which the value of the underlying data source changes or when the reported event takes place.
In order to facilitate integration in legacy environments oriented around polling style operations,
an option to support overriding the timestamp field to the send-time is available from EOS 4.27.0F.
notification_timestamp.title: Notification Timestamp

enable_vrfs.description:
Enable VRFs will be deprecated in AVD v4.0.
These should not be mixed with the new keys above.
enable_vrfs.title: Enable VRFs

octa.description:
Octa key will be deprecated in AVD v4.0.
These should not be mixed with the new keys above.
Octa activates `eos-native` provider and it is the only provider currently supported by EOS.
octa.title: Octa

default_services.description: Enable default services: capi-doc and tapagg
default_services.title: Default Services

source.description:
Source IP Address.
"source" and "source_interface" are mutually exclusive. If both are defined, "source_interface" takes precedence.
source.title: Source

source.description:
Source IP Address.
"source" and "source_interface" are mutually exclusive. If both are defined, "source_interface" takes precedence.
source.title: Source

address.description: Hostname or IP of remote engine
address.title: Address

remote_address.description:
Hostname or ip of remote engine
The remote_address and udp_port are used for remote users
remote_address.title: Remote Address

udp_port.description: udp_port will not be used if no remote_address is configured
udp_port.title: UDP Port

localized.description: Engine ID in hexadecimal for localizing auth and/or priv
localized.title: Localized

auth_passphrase.title: Auth Passphrase

priv_passphrase.description: Hashed privacy passphrase if localized is used else cleartext privacy passphrase
priv_passphrase.title: Priv Passphrase

name.description:
Enable or disable specific snmp-traps and their sub_traps
Examples:
- "bgp"
- "bgp established"
name.title: Name

count.description: Maximum number of BPDUs per timer interval
count.title: Count

action.description:
Action as string
Example: "deny ip any any"
action.title: Action

truncation_size.description: Allowed truncation_size values vary depending on the platform
truncation_size.title: Truncation Size

timestamp.description: mac.timestamp.replace_source_mac and mac.timestamp.header.format are mutually exclsuive. If both are defined, replace_source_mac takes precedence
timestamp.title: Timestamp

fcs_append.description: mac.fcs_append and mac.fcs_error are mutually exclusive. If both are defined, mac.fcs_append takes precedence
fcs_append.title: FCS Append

config.description:
TCAM Profile Config. Since these can be very long, it is often a good idea to import the config from a file.
Example: "{{lookup('file', '{{ root_dir }}/inventory/TCAM_TRAFFIC_POLICY.conf')}}"
config.title: Config

The 'fragment' command is not supported when 'source port'
or 'destination port' command is configured

ipv6_address_virtual.description:
IPv6_address/Mask
"ipv6_address_virtual" key will be deprecated in AVD v4.0 in favor of the new "ipv6_address_virtuals"
If both "ipv6_address_virtual" and "ipv6_address_virtuals" are set, all addresses will be configured
ipv6_address_virtual.title: IPv6 Address Virtual

ipv6_address_virtuals.title: IPv6 Address Virtuals

"ipv6_virtual_router_address" key will be deprecated in AVD v4.0
This should not be mixed with the new "ipv6_virtual_router_addresses" key below to avoid conflicts.

ipv6_virtual_router_addresses.description: Improved "VARPv6" data model to support multiple VARPv6 addresses.
ipv6_virtual_router_addresses.title: IPv6 Virtual Router Addresses

qos.description:
For the Traffic Class to be derived based on the outer DSCP field of the incoming VxLan packet, the core ports must be in "DSCP Trust" mode.
!!!Warning, only few hardware types with software version >= 4.26.0 support the below knobs to configure Vxlan DSCP mapping.

map_dscp_to_traffic_class_decapsulation.title: Map DSCP To Traffic Class Decapsulation
